message:
Turning EMACS into a Python IDE, you will never know the pleasure of coding until you do it on EMACS with auto complete :)

P.S. it took me ages to find this, I spent a week trying to do it 2 months ago but I gave up, then this made it very easy and I got to enjoy it finally, I couldn't sleep out of pure happiness. I am still looking for a way to set up a short cut to run the code in the buffer, would appreciate some Geeky input here
story: Mohamed Samy shared a link to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: Emacs as a Python editor and IDE (Part 1): Installing elpy mode
caption: youtube.com
description: How to make Emacs into a Python editor/IDE with elpy.el mode,which makes coding Python in Emacs easier w/Jedi and Rope.Details:http://onthecode.com/post/7881...

data.message: Here is my geeky input: use sublime with anaconda
Mohammad Tayseer I like the name Anaconda, but have you tried EMACS?

I tried emacs & vi. I didn't like any of them, because they are completely different universes. I use vi out of necessity. Sublime gives me the power of these editors, building on top of what I already know. I used to work with Notepad++, but Sublime has better keyboard handling.

With Sublime, I use Anaconda for Python integration. Anaconda can work with virtualenvs as well. Djaneiro for Django & jinja2 syntax highlighting. Emmet for HTML.

I'm using Django when I can. Flask cover all other cases that Django doesn't cover well.
i use sublime it's really powerful tool i ever met
Mohammad Tayseer i was a sublime addict .. but now Atom is cooler
